properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system from the United States will affect the province of Quebec beginning Sunday morning and spread rain over the southwest of the province. Rainfall amounts of 25 to 45 millimetres are expected over these areas through Monday evening. Flooding is possible in low lying areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-29T03:18:34-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rainfall possible Saturday night into Sunday. Rain, heavy at times, is forecast to begin overnight Saturday and continue into Sunday. Thunderstorms may accompany the rain, starting in Southwestern Ontario in the evening and spreading towards the Ontario-Quebec border by noon Sunday. Total rainfall amounts could exceed 25 mm in very localized areas that receive multiple rounds of heavy rain in thunderstorms. There is considerable uncertainty regarding where the highest rainfall amounts are expected. Rainfall warnings with the criteria of 25 mm within 24 hours where the ground remains frozen may be required at a later time should heavier rainfall amounts become more likely. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-29T01:16:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-28T09:17:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1316433011.2020

properties.Title: Civil Emergency Alert Issued By Government Of Saskatchewan
properties.Summary:
Description: This Alert is issued by the Government of Saskatchewan. If you are returning to Canada from foreign travel, you MUST self-isolate for 14 days. This includes travel from the US, which now has more COVID 19 cases than any country in the world. It’s the law. For more information on COVID 19 visit: Saskatchewan.ca COVID 19

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy wet snow expected Saturday night through Sunday afternoon. A strong spring storm system will bring a rain and snow mix to the area for overnight Saturday through Sunday. Highly localized total snowfall amounts up to 15 cm are possible by Sunday afternoon. However, the track of the low and the resulting amount of rain and snow has considerable uncertainty at this point. Untreated surfaces may become slippery. Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-29T01:16:01-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard Saturday afternoon and night. On Saturday, another low pressure system will track through the area bringing strong winds and more accumulating snow. In Arviat, conditions will deteriorate to sustained blizzard Saturday afternoon as northwesterlies gusting to 70 or 80 km/h develop along with up to 5 cm of fresh snow. Near zero visibilities at times are likely. The blizzard will continue through the night before easing Sunday morning as the skies clear and winds diminish. In Rankin Inlet including Whale Cove, northerly winds gusting up to 70 km/h with a few cm of accumulating snow create blizzard conditions with visibilities near zero at times in falling and blowing snow beginning Saturday evening and last until Sunday early afternoon. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-29T00:20:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-28T08:21:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0358170511.2020
Area: Arviat, Rankin Region including Whale Cove
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme cold wind chill values near minus 55 will moderate today as temperatures rise. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-28T19:59:56-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Locations: Makkovik to Nain. Further snowfall: 10 to 20 cm, except 2 to 4 cm in Nain. Maximum wind gusts: north to northwest 80 km/h except near 100 km/h this morning. Time span: ending by this evening. Remarks: Snow will continue to combine with strong northerly winds to create near zero visibility in blowing snow today. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. Snow, at times heavy, will continue through the weekend. The heaviest snow is expected to fall tonight. Accumulations will likely be variable across the region, but by Sunday evening total snowfall amounts could be near 30 cm in some areas. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Further snowfall: 5 to 10 cm. Locations: Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River, and Rigolet and vicinity. Time span: ending by this evening. Remarks: The heaviest snowfall is expected this morning, with snowfall rates easing this afternoon. Northwesterly winds gusting up to 70 km/h will combine with the fresh snowfall to reduce visibility in blowing snow at times today, especially over exposed areas. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system from the United States will affect the province of Quebec Sunday and Monday. Snowfall amounts of more than 15 centimetres are possible for Central Quebec. However, precipitation amounts could greatly vary according to region as temperatures will be near the freezing mark. Some areas near and south of the St. Lawrence river could see primarily rain, while snowfall amounts of 25 centimetres will likely be locally over higher terrain. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult in some areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-28T23:58:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-28T07:59:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3648477352.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Rain will change to snow this evening and become heavy when an Arctic front arrives. Along with the heavy snow, the Arctic front will bring northeast winds gusting to 60 km/h giving reduced visibility in blowing snow. About 15 cm of snow is expected tonight with an additional 5 to 15 on Saturday. Total snowfall accumulations are expected to reach near 30 cm by Saturday afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-28T15:12:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-27T23:13:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1151080312.2020
Area: Highway 97 - Pine Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Adverse Winter Driving Conditions Due to Heavy Snow This Weekend. An unseasonably cool spring storm will deliver significant snow to the high mountain passes of southern B.C. Snow will continue today as the system pushes across British Columbia. In the wake of the system on Sunday, intense bursts of flurries will add further accumulations. Gusty winds will reduce visibilities in blowing snow, particularly on Sunday. Snow levels will be unseasonably low, hovering between 1100 and 1400 metres. A transition from rain at the lower elevations to heavy snow near the passes will make for adverse winter driving conditions. Motorists are encouraged to consider delaying travel plans until early next week when the snow will ease in the mountains. Drivers should be prepared for winter driving conditions and are reminded that winter tires are mandatory until April 30th. Please check the highway forecasts before heading out and stay tuned for potential snowfall warnings. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-29T02:36:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-28T10:37:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2187495084.2020
Area: Highway 3 - Hope to Princeton via Allison Pass, Okanagan Connector - Merritt to Kelowna
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. South winds gusting near 90 kilometres per hour will develop in this locality on Sunday morning. These winds will persist until late in the day. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. An unseasonably cool spring storm will bring a long period of snowfall over the highway passes this weekend with 20 to 30 cm of snow expected for Rogers Pass and Kootenay Pass. The Coquihalla Hope to Merritt segment may see 30 to 40 cm. Snow will fall today at the highest elevations but will fall in earnest beginning tonight. As a cold front sweeps across the province on Sunday, an unsettled airmass will result in brief but intense bursts of flurries over the highways with sudden reduction in visibility due to heavy snow. Be aware of sudden changes in road conditions and visibility, particularly near the highway summits. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-29T02:43:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-28T10:44:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1581030799.2020
Area: Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass, Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt, Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Total snowfall: an additional 15 cm in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: 50 km/h. Locations: western Cape Breton. Time span: this evening and overnight. Remarks: Flurries at times heavy with risk of snow squalls will persist tonight, then end Saturday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-28T12:59:37-00:00
